header.title: Three Books of Occult Philosophy, or of Magick. Book I.

central_thesis: The universe is a tripartite, hierarchical structure (Elementary, Celestial, Intellectual) where divine 'Vertues' descend from God through Angels, Stars, and Elements to all things. Magick is the supreme philosophy that enables a practitioner, through knowledge of Natural, Mathematical (Celestial), and Theological (Ceremonial) principles, to ascend this hierarchy, draw forth these virtues, and manipulate both natural and supernatural phenomena by understanding and applying the principles of similitude, sympathy, and celestial correspondences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. i. How Magicians Collect vertues from the three-fold World, is declared in these three Books.
structure_content.summary: Introduces the cosmic hierarchy of the Elementary, Celestial, and Intellectual Worlds, where divine influences flow downwards. It asserts that magicians can reverse this flow to draw virtues from above and outlines the three branches of magic (Natural, Celestial, Ceremonial) that will be covered in the book.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. ii. What Magick is, What are the Parts thereof, and how the Professors thereof must be Qualified.
structure_content.summary: Defines Magick as the pinnacle of philosophy, a 'faculty of wonderfull vertue' encompassing the knowledge of nature, power, and qualities. It explicitly links Magick's three parts (Natural, Celestial, Ceremonial) to Natural, Mathematical, and Theological Philosophy, respectively, and details the rigorous qualifications (skills in all three philosophies) required for a practitioner.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. iii. Of the four Elements, their qualities, and mutuall mixtions.
structure_content.summary: Explores the fundamental nature of the four elements (Fire, Earth, Water, Air) as the basis of all corporeal things. It describes their specific qualities (hot/cold, dry/moist), their contrarieties, and how they transmute and unite to form all compounds in the elementary world.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. iv. Of a three-fold consideration of the Elements.
structure_content.summary: Expands on the elements by categorizing them into three orders: 'pure' (uncompounded, incorruptible), 'compounded' (changeable, reducible to simplicity), and 'twice compounded' (the 'middle nature' or 'Soul of the middle nature'). Mastery of these distinctions is crucial for magical operations, including bindings, transmutations, and divination.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. v. Of the wonderfull Natures of Fire, and Earth.
structure_content.summary: Details Fire as the active principle and Earth as the passive principle. It describes Fire's properties (bright, occult, boundless, life-giving, consuming) and its celestial vs. infernal manifestations, and Earth's role as the 'foundation of all Elements' and a receptacle of celestial rays, both holding 'great secrets' for purification and medicine.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. vi. Of the wonderfull Natures of Water, Aire, and Winds.
structure_content.summary: Continues the elemental analysis with Water (essential for life, seed virtue, spiritual regeneration) and Air ('vitall spirit,' medium for celestial influences, a 'divine Looking-glass' for species and speeches, source of dreams and divinations). It also discusses the four principal winds and their characteristics.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. vii. Of the kinds of Compounds, what relation they stand in to the Elements, and what relation there is betwixt the Elements themselves, and the soul, senses, and dispositions of men.
structure_content.summary: Establishes correspondences between the four elements and compounded bodies (Stones, Metals, Plants, Animals), noting the predominant element in each. It then extends this system to the human microcosm, mapping elements to humors, body parts (bones, flesh, spirit), faculties of the soul (understanding, reason, imagination, senses), and human dispositions (slow, fearful, cheerful, angry).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. viii. How the Elements are in the Heavens, in Stars, in Divels [devils], in Angels, and lastly in God himself.
structure_content.summary: Asserts the ubiquitous presence of the elements across all hierarchical levels of the cosmos: in gross inferior bodies, more purely in the Heavens, in Stars (fiery, airy, watery, earthy), in Devils (fiery, earthy, airy, watery rivers), in Angels (stability, mercy, breath, love), and ultimately in God. It explains that elements exist as Ideas in the exemplary world, powers in Intelligences, virtues in Heavens, and gross forms in inferior bodies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. ix. Of the vertues of things Naturall, depending immediatly upon Elements.
structure_content.summary: Categorizes natural virtues into 'first qualities' (elemental, changing substance), 'secondary qualities' (from compounded elements, acting on members), and 'third qualities' (curing diseases). It details how these elemental principles can be manipulated to create artificial wonders, such as incombustible fires or self-consuming liquids.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. x. Of the Occult Vertues of things.
structure_content.summary: Introduces 'occult virtues' as distinct from elemental ones, arising from the 'species, and form' of things, with hidden causes beyond human reason and discovered primarily through experience. Numerous examples are given, such as the loadstone's attraction, the diamond's negation, and herbs/stones with specific magical effects like invisibility, healing, or calling spirits.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xi. How Occult Vertues are infused into the severall kinds of things by Idea's, through the help of the Soul of the World, and rayes of the Stars: and what things abound most with this Vertue.
structure_content.summary: Explains the Platonic-Hermetic origin of occult virtues: they are infused into things via 'Idea's' (divine forms) from God, mediated by the 'Soul of the World' (containing seminal forms) and the 'rayes of the Stars' (stamping properties). The purity of matter and alignment with celestial influences determine the efficacy of these virtues.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xii. How it is that particular Vertues are infused into particular Individuals, even of the same Species.
structure_content.summary: Discusses how unique virtues are instilled in individuals (beyond species) through their specific celestial configurations (horoscope, constellation) at the moment of their generation. It highlights the role of the 'obedientialness of matter' to the Soul of the World and the imaginative faculty of both celestial intelligences and the human operator.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xiii. Whence the Occult Vertues of things proceed.
structure_content.summary: Re-examines the source of occult virtues, synthesizing various philosophical views (Plato, Avicen, Hermes) into a unified system where God is the ultimate origin, conveying virtues through 'Idea's' to Intelligences, then through Heavens and Stars, which dispose matter and imbue specific forms. 'Miracles' are explained as God acting directly, bypassing secondary causes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xiv. Of the Spirit of the World, what it is, and how by way of medium it unites occult Vertues to their subjects.
structure_content.summary: Defines the 'Spirit of the World' as the 'quintessence,' a subtle, non-elemental medium that unites Celestial Souls to gross bodies and conveys occult properties from stellar rays to all natural things. It mentions alchemists' attempts to extract this spirit for transmutation and asserts its potent generative virtues.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xv. How we must find out, and examine the Vertues of things by way of similitude.
structure_content.summary: Outlines the primary method for discovering occult virtues: observation, experience, and especially the principle of 'similitude' or 'like attracts like.' It provides numerous examples of how parts of animals and plants are chosen based on their perceived qualities to induce desired effects, emphasizing the importance of taking parts when the animal's affection is most intense.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xvi. How the operations of several Vertues pass from one thing into another, and are communicated one to the other.
structure_content.summary: Explains that virtues can be transmitted from one object to another, infusing a similar power. Examples include the loadstone imparting attraction to iron rings, a harlot's boldness transferring to her garments, or the influence of objects from dead bodies imparting sadness, illustrating a principle of magical contagion.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xvii. How by enmity and friendship the vertues of things are to be tryed, and found out.
structure_content.summary: Introduces the concepts of 'enmity and friendship' (sympathy and antipathy) as fundamental relationships governing virtues across all levels of the cosmos – elemental, celestial (planetary), and terrestrial (minerals, plants, animals). Understanding these attractions and repulsions is key to effective magical practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xviii. Of the Inclinations of Enmities.
structure_content.summary: Provides extensive examples of specific enmities and antipathies in the natural world, detailing how certain substances, plants, and animals repel each other or counteract specific ailments. These include medicinal applications (e.g., rhubarb against choler) and protective uses against various creatures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xix. How the Vertues of things are to be tryed and found out, which are in them specifically, or in any one Individuall by way of speciall gift.
structure_content.summary: Distinguishes between virtues inherent to a species (e.g., lion's boldness) and those unique to individuals (e.g., a specific man immune to poison), emphasizing that individual gifts arise from particular celestial influences and can be identified through unique manifestations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xx. That naturall Vertues are in some things throughout their whole substance, and in other things in certain parts, and members.
structure_content.summary: Explores the localization of natural virtues: some reside throughout the entire substance of a thing (e.g., the Echeneis fish stopping ships), while others are concentrated in specific parts or members (e.g., basilisk's eyes killing by sight, human bones for life). This distinction guides the selection of magical ingredients.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxi. Of the Vertues of things which are in them only in their life time, and such as remain in them even after their death.
structure_content.summary: Differentiates between virtues that are active only when a creature is alive (e.g., the Echeneis stopping ships) and those that persist or become potent after death (e.g., eagle feathers destroying other feathers). It provides specific instructions for obtaining and applying these virtues, often emphasizing the importance of taking parts from living animals and their subsequent treatment.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxii. How inferior things are subjected to superior bodies, and how the bodies, the actions, and dispositions of men are ascribed to Stars, and Signes.
structure_content.summary: Establishes a detailed system of astrological correspondences, showing how human bodies, actions, and dispositions are governed by planets and zodiacal signs. It provides extensive lists of body parts, temperaments, and professions ruled by each celestial body, drawing on Arabian and Hermetic doctrines.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxiii. How we shall know what Stars naturall things are under, and what things are under the Sun, which are called Solary.
structure_content.summary: Explains how to determine a thing's planetary rulership (by its imitation of celestial rays, motion, figure, color, odor, or effects). It then provides an exhaustive list of 'Solary' (Sun-governed) items across elements, humors, tastes, metals, stones, plants, and animals, detailing their characteristics and magical properties.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxiv. What things are Lunary, or under the power of the Moon.
structure_content.summary: Enumerates 'Lunary' (Moon-governed) things, including elements (Earth, Water, moist things), tastes (salt, insipid), metals (Silver), stones (Crystal, Selenites), plants (Selenotropion, Hyssop), and animals (dogs, chameleons, cats). It emphasizes properties related to moisture, whiteness, changeability, and mimicry of lunar cycles.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxv. What things are Saturnine, or under the power of Saturne.
structure_content.summary: Catalogues 'Saturnine' things, characterizing them by darkness, heaviness, bitterness, slowness, solitude, and melancholy. It lists specific elements (Earth, Water), humors (black choler), tastes (sour, tart), metals (Lead, Gold), stones (Onyx, Sapphire), plants (Mandrake, Opium, burial trees), and animals (apes, cats, moles, dragons, owls) associated with Saturn's influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxvi. What things are under the power of Jupiter, and are called Jovial.
structure_content.summary: Details 'Jovial' things, aligning them with Jupiter's influences of increase, nourishment, wisdom, and honor. It provides extensive lists of elements (Air), humors (blood), tastes (sweet), metals (Tin, Silver, Gold), stones (Hyacinth, Emerald), plants (Oak, Vine), and animals (hart, elephant, eagle) that resonate with Jupiter.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxvii. What things are under the power of Mars, and are called Martial.
structure_content.summary: Presents 'Martial' things, characterized by fire, sharpness, bitterness, warfare, and aggressive traits, corresponding to Mars. It lists elements (Fire), humors (choler), metals (Iron, Red Brass), stones (Diamond, Blood-stone), plants (Hellebore, Wolfs-bane), and animals (horse, wolf, eagle) associated with Mars's energies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxviii. What things are under the power of Venus, and are called Venereall.
structure_content.summary: Describes 'Venereal' things, associated with Venus's influences of sweetness, beauty, love, and fertility. It lists elements (Air, Water), humors (blood, seed), tastes (delectable), metals (Silver, Brass), stones (Beryl, Emerald), plants (Rose, Myrtle), and animals (dogs, pigeons, swans) that embody Venusian qualities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxix. What things are under the power of Mercury, and are called Mercuriall.
structure_content.summary: Details 'Mercurial' things, linking them to Mercury's attributes of versatility, mixed qualities, quickness, ingenuity, and communication. It lists elements (Water), humors (mixed), tastes (various), metals (Quicksilver), stones (Achates, Topaz), plants (Hazel, Parsley), and animals (foxes, civet cats, parrots) that correspond to Mercury.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxx. That the whole sublunary World, and those things which are in it, are distributed to Planets.
structure_content.summary: Broadens the planetary correspondences to the entire sublunary world, detailing how each planet governs specific aspects of elements (e.g., Sun for Fire's light, Moon for Earth's surface), active/passive causes, and general properties of vegetables (e.g., Jupiter for fruit, Venus for flowers) and stones (e.g., Saturn for weight, Sun for life).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxi. How Provinces, and Kingdomes are distributed to Planets.
structure_content.summary: Maps out the astrological rulership of various provinces and kingdoms across the Earth to specific planets and zodiacal signs (e.g., Macedonia to Saturn/Capricorn, Italy to Sun/Leo). This knowledge is presented as crucial for prophetic divination concerning regional events and destinies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxii. What things are under the Signes, the fixed Stars, and their Images.
structure_content.summary: Establishes correspondences between terrestrial things and zodiacal signs (e.g., Ram to Aries, Lions to Leo) and fixed stars (e.g., Head of Algol to Diamond). It provides extensive lists of plants, animals, and stones ruled by specific celestial entities, noting that items can be influenced by multiple stars simultaneously.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxiii. Of the Seals, and Characters of Naturall things.
structure_content.summary: Explains that all natural things bear 'Seals and Characters' impressed by stellar rays, which contain the specific virtues of their governing stars. These characters, found in nature (plants, animal bones, stones), can be used in magic when stamped on 'fit matter' at 'due times.' Chiromancy is presented as a method of reading these 'divine letters' in human hands.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxiv. How by Naturall things, and their vertues we may draw forth, and attract the influencies, and vertues of Celestiall bodies.
structure_content.summary: Describes the practical method for attracting celestial virtues by selecting natural things corresponding to a particular star and applying them in specific ways to activate their latent powers. This involves assembling 'things of the same subject' that conform to a particular 'Idea' and 'Star' under a favorable celestial harmony.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxv. Of the Mixtions of naturall things, one with another, and their benefits.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the importance of 'mixtions' or compounding natural things to gather dispersed virtues into a unified form. It distinguishes between naturally embedded virtues and those achieved through 'artificiall mixtion' at opportune astrological times, emphasizing the principle of 'likeness and aptness' for effective combination.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxvi. Of the Union of mixt things, and the introduction of a more noble form, and the Senses of life.
structure_content.summary: Focuses on the creation of 'more noble forms' by infusing life and a 'sensible soul' into prepared mixtures through celestial influences. It describes how this process, dependent on perfect mixtures and aligned qualities, can lead to 'monstrous generations' and potent magical effects, explaining that celestial virtue lies dormant until activated in living bodies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxvii. How by some certain naturall, and artificiall preparations we may attract certain Celestiall, and vitall Gifts.
structure_content.summary: Explains the universal principle of hierarchical attraction, or 'sympathies,' as the mechanism for drawing celestial, vital, intellectual, and divine gifts. It states that nature itself is a 'Magicianess' operating on 'like by like,' and details how specific preparations align inferior things with superior powers in a continuous chain of influence from God to the material world.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxviii. How we may draw not only Celestiall, and vitall, but also certain Intellectuall, and divine gifts from above.
structure_content.summary: Expands the scope of magical attraction to include Intellectual and Divine gifts. It cites authorities like Trismegistus and the Platonists, asserting that specific materials imbued with 'natural power of divinity,' when properly prepared, can draw forth angelic and divine influences, leading to prophecy, revival of the dead, and visions of spirits.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xxxix. That we may by some certain matters of the world stir up the Gods of the world, and their ministring spirits.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the invocation of 'Gods of the world' (celestial intelligences) and their ministring spirits. It contrasts methods for raising evil spirits (profane arts, sacrifices) with those for good spirits (purity, prayer) and explains how ancient priests animated statues with star spirits, causing them to perform wonders.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xl. Of bindings, what sort they are of, and in what wayes they are wont to be done.
structure_content.summary: Introduces 'bindings' as a powerful form of magic used to constrain or influence various entities and phenomena, from men to ships and natural forces (e.g., preventing theft, stopping mills, curing sickness). It lists diverse operative methods, including sorceries, collyries, unguents, rings, charms, images, invocations, and superstitions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xli. Of Sorceries, and their power.
structure_content.summary: Illustrates the immense power of 'Sorceries' to 'subvert, consume, and change all inferiour things,' drawing on literary (Circe, Thessala) and historical accounts. It details examples such as transforming men into beasts, summoning ghosts, and causing love or other desired effects through potent, often grotesque, ingredients and rituals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xlii. Of the wonderful vertues of some kinds of Sorceries.
structure_content.summary: Provides explicit and detailed instructions for various sorceries, focusing on the highly potent and often dangerous uses of menstruous blood (e.g., spoiling wine, cursing plants, curing fevers, causing barrenness) and 'Hippomanes' (a substance from mares used to procure love or invulnerability). It also lists other ingredients like Prometheus herb and animal parts for diverse effects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xliii. Of Perfumes, or Suffumigations, their manner, and power.
structure_content.summary: Explains the 'great force' of 'suffumigations' (fumes and perfumes) in attracting celestial gifts and manipulating spirits by affecting the Air and breath. It provides numerous recipes and instructions for specific fumes using animal parts, herbs, and resins to induce prophecy, reveal spirits, drive away evil, or cause weather phenomena, emphasizing planetary correspondences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xliv. The Composition of some fumes appropriated to the Planets.
structure_content.summary: Offers specific recipes for planetary suffumigations, detailing ingredients (e.g., Saffron and Eagle brain for the Sun, Frog head and Menstruous blood for the Moon, black Poppy and Cat brain for Saturn) to be compounded into pills or troches. It also lists general odoriferous materials for each planet and zodiacal sign, distinguishing between 'good' and 'stinking' fumes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xlv. Of Collyries, Unctions, Love-Medicines, and their vertues.
structure_content.summary: Describes the transformative power of 'Collyries' (eye salves) and 'Unguents,' which convey virtues to the practitioner's 'spirit,' affecting the body, nearby objects, and perceptions. It includes recipes for collyries to see spirits, and explains how magical confections, along with specific gestures and passions, can induce sickness, love, or even physical transfiguration.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xlvi. Of naturall alligations, and suspensions.
structure_content.summary: Explains 'natural alligations and suspensions' as methods of applying objects (wrapped, bound, or by contact) to impress virtues onto a person. It details how these can change body/mind accidents (sickness, joy, love) and provides examples like using a cramp-fish to stupefy or a specific thread/needle charm to prevent sexual activity, all dependent on precise astrological timing and material suitability.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xlvii. Of Rings, and their compositions.
structure_content.summary: Details the magical properties and composition of rings, asserting their ability to impress virtues (e.g., gladness, courage, protection). It provides instructions for making rings under fortunate stellar conjunctions, incorporating stones, herbs, and metals corresponding to the chosen star, along with appropriate images, characters, and suffumigations, citing historical examples of powerful rings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xlviii. Of the vertue of places, and what places are sutable to every Star.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the inherent magical virtues of places, which can derive from local objects or stellar influences. It maps various types of locations (e.g., stinking places for Saturn, pleasant fountains for Venus, fiery places for Mars) to specific planets and zodiacal signs, and provides instructions for orienting oneself during magical operations based on these correspondences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. xlix. Of Light, Colours, Candles, and Lamps, and to what Stars, Houses, and Elements severall colours are ascribed.
structure_content.summary: Explores light and colors as expressions of divine influence, detailing how magical lamps and candles, composed under specific stellar rules, can produce wondrous visual effects (e.g., visions of horse heads or scattered stars). It provides extensive planetary, zodiacal, and elemental correspondences for various colors, explaining their philosophical basis and practical use.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. l. Of Fascination, and the Art thereof.
structure_content.summary: Defines 'fascination' as a 'binding' of the bewitched person's heart through the witch's 'spirit' transmitted via eye rays. It explains the mechanism of reciprocal gazing and strong imagination for fixing spirits and creating 'vehement loves,' and how specific collyries and unguents can be used for love, fear, or sickness.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. li. Of certain observations, producing wonderfull Vertues.
structure_content.summary: Documents a wide array of specific magical 'observations' and rituals, often involving unusual ingredients and precise actions, to produce effects such as curing fevers (e.g., nail parings with eels), easing childbirth, procuring love, or preventing barking dogs. These practices rely on sympathetic magic and specific timings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lii. Of the Countenance, and Gesture, the Habit, and Figure of the Body, and to what Stars any of these do answer; whence Physiognomy, and Metoposcopy, and Chyromancy [Chiromancy], Arts of divination, have their grounds.
structure_content.summary: Establishes the astrological foundation of physiognomy, metoposcopy (face reading), and chiromancy (palmistry) by linking human countenance, gesture, body shape, and disposition to planetary influences. It details how each planet manifests in physical and behavioral traits and asserts that consciously imitating celestial bodies can attract greater gifts.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. liii. Of Divination, and its kinds.
structure_content.summary: Categorizes different forms of 'Divination,' including natural presages from physicians and husbandmen, and Roman auguries/auspices derived from birds, animals, celestial phenomena (thunder, lightning), and sacrifices. It details specific augury types (e.g., Michael Scotus's twelve kinds) and their interpretations, along with presages from sneezes and unconscious speech.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. liiii. Of divers certain Animals, and other things which have a signification in Auguria's [auguries].
structure_content.summary: Provides an extensive catalog of animal behaviors and appearances as omens, detailing their interpretations for foretelling future events (e.g., rats gnawing garments as ill omen, cock crowing for hours of day/night). It differentiates between good and bad omens from various creatures, from daws and eagles to mice and snakes, emphasizing the principle of natural instinct as a prophetic medium.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lv. How Auspica's are verified by the light of Naturall instinct, and of some rules of finding of it out.
structure_content.summary: Explores how auspices and auguries are verified through 'natural instinct,' a sublime form of divination that allows animals (e.g., dogs detecting thieves, vultures foreseeing slaughter) to perceive future events. It discusses how these 'lights of presage' are manifest in animals' gestures, motions, voices, and colors, providing principles for interpretation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lvi. Of the Sooth sayings of Flashes, and Lightenings, and how Monstrous, and prodigious things are to be interpreted.
structure_content.summary: Explains divination through 'Flashes and Lightnings' (Hetruscan doctrine) and the interpretation of 'monstrous and prodigious things' as presages of great matters. It provides numerous historical examples of omens preceding significant events like the births of kings or major destructions, emphasizing the principle of 'same for same, like for like' for interpretation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lvii. Of Geomancy, Hydromancy, Aeromancy, Pyromancy, four Divinations of Elements.
structure_content.summary: Introduces the four elemental divinations: Geomancy (by earth's motions or points), Hydromancy (by water's impressions, visions, or melting substances), Aeromancy (by air's phenomena like winds and clouds), and Pyromancy (by fire's appearances and smoke). It offers historical examples and specific interpretations for each method.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lviii. Of the reviving of the dead, and of sleeping, and wanting victuals many years together.
structure_content.summary: Discusses accounts of reviving the dead and prolonged states of sleep or fasting, drawing on philosophical beliefs and historical examples. It suggests that many cases of revival involved individuals in deep trances rather than true death, and details specific magical or herbal methods for inducing or treating these states, often linked to 'like attracts like' principles.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lix. Of Divination by Dreams.
structure_content.summary: Examines 'Divination by Dreams,' distinguishing true prophetic dreams (from celestial influences acting on the 'phantastick spirit') from idle imaginings. It emphasizes the importance of observation, memory, and individual disposition for interpreting dreams and notes that dreams are more efficacious under specific lunar phases.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lx. Of Madness, and Divinations which are made when men are awake, and of the power of a Melancholy humor, by which Spirits are sometimes induced into mens bodies.
structure_content.summary: Explores 'Divination' during waking states ('ravishment' or madness), attributing it to a 'melancholy humor' (specifically 'natural, white choler') and Saturn's influence. It describes a threefold process (Imaginative, Rational, Intellectual) by which this humor, intensified by celestial influx, allows for manual arts, predictions of natural events, or even divine revelation through induced spirits.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxi. Of the forming of Man, of the external Senses, and also the Inward, and the Mind: of the threefold appetite of the Soul, and passions of the Will.
structure_content.summary: Presents a detailed philosophical and psychological model of humanity, from its formation by heavenly spirits to the structure of the soul, its external and internal senses, and the three appetites (natural, animal, intellective/will). It meticulously defines the will's passions (Oblectation, Effusion, Vaunting, Envy) as arising from a 'depraved appetite for pleasure.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxii. Of the Passions of the Mind, their Original [origin], difference, and kinds.
structure_content.summary: Systematizes the 'Passions of the Mind' by tracing their origin to three types of apprehension (sensual, rational, intellectual) and the concupiscible and irascible powers of the soul. It meticulously lists and defines the eleven primary passions (Love, Hatred, Desire, Horror, Joy, Grief, Hope, Despair, Boldness, Fear, Anger) within this structured framework.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxiii. How the passions of the mind change the proper body, by changing the Accidents, and moving the spirit.
structure_content.summary: Explains how intense 'passions of the mind,' driven by the 'phantasy,' physically alter the body through 'sensible transmutation' and movement of the 'spirit.' It provides numerous physiological examples of how emotions manifest physically (e.g., joy dilates the heart, fear causes paleness), and their potential to cause or cure diseases, even leading to death in extreme cases.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxiv. How the Passions of the mind change the body by way of imitation from some resemblance; Also of the transforming, and translating of men, and what force the imaginative power hath not only over the body, but the soul.
structure_content.summary: Details how 'passions of the mind' can alter the body through 'imitation' based on resemblance (e.g., seeing someone yawn makes one yawn). It emphasizes the profound power of 'imaginative power' to transform the body (e.g., horns from intense meditation) and soul, induce involuntary actions, and even transport individuals, citing numerous historical and philosophical examples.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxv. How the Passions of the Mind can work out of themselves upon anothers Body.
structure_content.summary: Explores how vehement 'passions of the mind' can transcend the individual to affect 'another's Body' or the external world, leading to phenomena like bewitchment, monstrous births (from maternal imagination), and the spread of sickness. It posits the mind as a powerful force capable of conveying both beneficial and harmful influences through contagion and imagination, advocating for avoiding evil company and seeking good.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxvi. That the Passions of the mind are helped by a Celestiall season, and how necessary the Constancy of the mind is in every work.
structure_content.summary: Stresses the crucial role of the magician's internal state—'constancy of mind,' vehement intention, strong belief, hope, and love—for successful magical operations. It explains that aligning one's mind and affections with celestial influences, as confirmed by Ptolemy and medical practice, amplifies the reception of divine gifts, while doubt dissipates virtue.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxvii. How mans mind may be joyned with the mind, and Intelligencies of the Celestials, and together with them impress certain wonderfull vertues upon inferiour things.
structure_content.summary: Explains that the human mind, when intensely focused through passion and affection, can unite with Celestial Intelligences and impress powerful virtues onto inferior things. It asserts that strong desires, combined with knowledge of universal powers, are key to verifying magical 'Arts of Characters, images, enchantments, and speeches,' leading to effects like love or destruction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxviii. How our mind can change, and bind inferiour things to that which it desires.
structure_content.summary: Describes the mind's ability to 'change and bind inferior things' through vehement affection and the principle of 'superior binds inferior.' It uses examples of natural antipathies (Lion/Cock, Diamond/Loadstone) and planetary influences to show how a magician can exert control for various effects (e.g., love, fear, servitude), and how such bindings can be dissolved.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxix. Of Speech, and the vertue of Words.
structure_content.summary: Explores the 'virtue of words and speech,' distinguishing between internal (mind's conception) and uttered words. It argues that uttered words, as vehicles of the mind and speaker's virtue, possess significant power to influence hearers and inanimate objects, especially when representing higher (intellectual, celestial) things, and are more efficacious when spoken from a 'worthy tongue.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxx. Of the vertue of proper names.
structure_content.summary: Affirms the critical 'virtue of proper names' in magical operations, explaining that names contain the essence and power of the things they signify. These names, derived from both celestial harmony and human imposition (as Adam named creatures), are most efficacious when uttered with serious intention at the proper place and time, as demonstrated by historical examples of revival and city conjuration.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxxi. Of many words joyned together, as in sentences, and verses, and of the vertues, and astrictions of charms.
structure_content.summary: Highlights the heightened power of sentences, verses, and charms over single words, derived from their contained truth, structure, and the magician's vehement affection and imagination. It provides detailed instructions for composing and delivering invocations based on planetary virtues, emphasizing the 'harmoniacall spirit' of the enchanter, and notes that words can induce effects even when written backwards.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxxii. Of the wonderful power of Inchantments [Enchantments].
structure_content.summary: Illustrates the 'wonderful power of enchantments' through numerous literary and historical examples (Circe, Thessala, Virgil, Ovid). It shows their capacity to manipulate natural laws, celestial bodies, weather, transform beings, induce love, and heal diseases, citing even legal statutes against enchanting fruit as evidence of their perceived efficacy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxxiii. Of the vertue of writting [writing], and of making imprecations, and inscriptions.
structure_content.summary: Emphasizes the 'virtue of writing' as a potent magical act, being the ultimate expression of the mind. It instructs magicians to include 'imprecations and inscriptions' in their works to declare purpose and affection, citing Albertus Magnus and Virgil's examples of written charms and symbolic actions for love and other effects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. lxxiv. Of the proportion, correspondency, reduction of Letters to the Celestiall Signs, and Planets, according to various tongues, and a Table shewing this.
structure_content.summary: Details the correspondences between letters (Hebrew, Greek, Latin) and celestial bodies (planets, zodiacal signs, elements). It highlights the mystical significance of the Hebrew alphabet, explaining how letter forms, numbers, and pronunciations are used in magic and divination to access divine and celestial powers, concluding with a table illustrating these reductions.

key_concepts.definition: A hierarchical cosmic structure comprising the Elementary (material), Celestial (astral/planetary), and Intellectual (divine/angelic) realms, where inferior levels are governed by and receive influence from superior ones.

Divine powers or influences originating from God and conveyed through the three-fold world (Angels, Stars, Elements, etc.) into all things. These are distinct from elemental qualities, often hidden, and known primarily through experience and the principle of similitude. They are infused by 'Idea's' through the 'Soul of the World' and 'rayes of the Stars'.

A subtle, non-elemental 'first thing' that acts as a universal medium, uniting Celestial Souls to gross bodies and conveying occult virtues from the stars into terrestrial things. Alchemists seek to extract this spirit.

The fundamental magical principle that 'every thing moves, and turns itself to its like, and inclines that to itself with all its might.' This principle governs the infusion and attraction of virtues, where things with similar properties (occult, elementary, or even substantial) influence one another.

Inherent relationships between all things, determining their attractions (friendship) or repulsions (enmity) across elemental, celestial, and terrestrial levels. Understanding these relationships is crucial for selecting appropriate magical ingredients and counteracting unwanted influences.

A form of 'binding' magic transmitted from the 'spirit of the Witch' through the eyes of the bewitched, entering the heart. It operates via visual rays carrying spiritual vapor and blood, intensified by reciprocal gazing and strong imagination, to induce love, sickness, or other effects.

Magical preparations involving burning specific ingredients to create vapors. These vapors act powerfully on the Air and practitioner's breath, affecting the imagination, attracting celestial gifts, revealing spirits, or influencing weather, based on their specific planetary or zodiacal correspondences.

A powerful magical operation intended to constrain or influence entities, people, animals, or natural phenomena for various effects (e.g., inducing love/hatred, causing sickness, preventing theft, stopping machinery). Methods include sorceries, collyries, unguents, rings, charms, images, invocations, and specific observations.

The intricate system of relationships linking all inferior things (elements, humors, body parts, animals, plants, minerals, places, colors, letters, human dispositions) to specific superior bodies (Planets, Zodiacal Signs, Fixed Stars). This system forms the basis for operative magic, allowing practitioners to align their actions with cosmic influences.

The inherent power within proper names, sentences, and verses, derived from celestial harmony and human imposition, and containing the essence of the things they signify. When uttered with vehement affection and intention, especially those representing intellectual or celestial concepts, they can impress virtues, bind, or effect transformations.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in Book I focuses on 'Natural Magic,' which involves collecting and manipulating the 'vertues' inherent in natural things through understanding their elemental and celestial correspondences. The core mechanic is the principle of 'similitude' (like attracts like), where objects, substances, or actions that resemble a desired celestial influence or terrestrial effect are used to draw forth or transfer that virtue. This includes specific rituals of collection, preparation, and application, often timed with opportune astrological moments.
tools: Natural Materials: Specific plants, herbs, roots (e.g., marigold, mandrake, vervain), animal parts (e.g., heart of lion, blood of pigeon, chameleon liver, civet cat gall), minerals and stones (e.g., loadstone, diamond, sapphire, emerald, ruby), metals (e.g., gold, silver, iron, lead, quicksilver), and other substances (e.g., menstruous blood, hippomanes, bitumen).
Magical Instruments: Rings, lamps, candles, vials, swords, staffs, vessels.

Planetary and Stellar Characters: Specific glyphs and 'divine letters' corresponding to planets (e.g., the symbols for Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon provided in the text) and stars, used for inscriptions on talismans, rings, or in rituals.

Astronomical/Astrological Knowledge: Charts and tables detailing planetary aspects, lunar phases, zodiacal signs, and their correspondences to specific places, times, colors, and natural objects are essential for timing and material selection.
rituals: Attracting Celestial Virtues: Select natural things (minerals, plants, animals, parts) corresponding to a desired star, combine them in opportune mixtures, and activate dormant virtues through specific actions (e.g., bruising, heating).

Alligations and Suspensions: Prepare items (wrapped, bound, or by simple contact) under specific constellations using materials (wire, silk, hair, animal skins) that match the desired planetary influence to impress virtues onto a person for effects like healing, protection, love, or aversion.

Rings and Talismans: Craft rings or talismans by taking stones, herbs, and metals corresponding to a beneficent star, embedding them, and inscribing planetary characters or images. This must be done at astrologically opportune times with proper suffumigations.

Suffumigations (Fumes/Perfumings): Create specific smoke or vapors from ingredients corresponding to planets or zodiacal signs (e.g., Saffron for the Sun, black Poppy for Saturn) mixed with animal parts (e.g., Eagle brain, Cat brain). These are used to attract celestial gifts, reveal spirits, induce prophecy, or cause weather effects.

Collyries and Unctions: Prepare salves and ointments from specific ingredients (e.g., gall of man, eyes of black cat for spirit sight) to act on the practitioner's 'spirit' or vision, causing transformations, love, or visions of spirits. Application through anointing or direct contact is key.

Divination by Observations: Interpret omens from animal behaviors (e.g., rats gnawing garments, crowing cocks), natural phenomena (e.g., lightning flashes, water movements), and specific physical signs to foretell future events or determine auspicious timing for actions.

relevant_quotes.text: Magick is a faculty of wonderfull vertue, full of most high mysteries, containing the most profound Contemplation of most secret things, together with the nature, power, quality, substance, and vertues thereof, as also the knowledge of whole nature, and it doth instruct us concerning the differing, and agreement of things amongst themselves, whence it produceth its wonderfull effects, by uniting the vertues of things through the application of them one to the other, and to their inferior sutable subjects, joyning and knitting them together thoroughly by the powers, and vertues of the superior Bodies. This is the most perfect and chief Science, that sacred and sublimer kind of Phylosophy [philosophy], and lastly the most absolute perfection of all most excellent Philosophy.

Jeeing there is a three-fold World, Elementary, Celestiall, and Intellectual, and every inferior is governed by its superior, and receiveth the influence of the vertues thereof, so that the very original, and chief Worker of all doth by Angels, the Heavens, Stars, Elements, Animals, Plants, Metals, and Stones convey from himself the vertues of his Omnipotency upon us, for whose service he made, and created all these things: Wise men conceive it no way irrationall that it should be possible for us to ascend by the same degrees through each World, to the same very originall World it self, the Maker of all things, and first Cause, from whence all things are, and proceed; and also to enjoy not only these vertues, which are already in the more excellent kind of things, but also besides these, to draw new vertues from above.

There are also other vertues in things, which are not from any Element, as to expell poyson [poison], to drive away the noxious vapours of Minerals, to attract Iron, or any thing else; and these vertues are a sequell of the species, and form of this or that thing; whence also they being little in quantity, are of great efficacy; which is not granted to any Elementary quality. For these vertues having much form, and litle matter, can do very much; but an Elementary vertue, because it hath more materiality, requires much matter for its acting. And they are called occult qualities, because their Causes lie hid, and mans intellect cannot in any way reach, and find them out. Wherefore Philosophers have attained to the greatest part of them by long experience, rather then by the search of reason.

Platonists say that all inferiour bodies are exemplified by the superiour Ideas. Now they define an Idea to be a form, above bodies, souls, minds, and to be one, simple, pure, immutable, indivisible, incorporeal, and eternall: and that the nature of all Idea's is the same. Now they place Idea's in the first place in very goodness it self (i.e.) God, by way of cause; and that they are distinguished amongst themselves by some relative considerations only, least whatsoever is in the world, should be but one thing without any variety, and that they agree in essence, least God should be a compound substance. In the second place, they place them in the very intelligible it self (i.e.) in the Soul of the world, differing the one from the other by absolute forms, so that all the Idea's in God indeed are but one form: but in the Soul of the world they are many. They are placed in the minds of all other things, whether they be joyned to the body, or separated from the body, by a certain participation, and now by degrees are distinguished more, and more. They place them in nature, as certain small seed of forms infused by the Idea's, and lastly they place them in matter, as Shadows.

There is therefore such a kind of spirit required to be, as it were the medium, whereby Celestiall Souls are joyned to gross bodies, and bestow upon them wonderfull gifts. This spirit is after the same manner in the body of the world, as ours is in the body of man. For as the powers of our soul are communicated to the members of the body by the spirit, so also the Vertue of the Soul of the World is diffused through all things by the quintessence: For there is nothing found in the whole world, that hath not a spark of the Vertue thereof.

Every thing moves, and turns it self to its like, and inclines that to it self with all its might, as well in property, viz. Occult vertue, as in quality, viz. Elementary vertue. Sometimes also in substance it self, as we see in Salt, for whatsoever hath long stood with Salt, becomes Salt: for every agent, when it hath begun to act, doth not attempt to make a thing inferiour to it self, but as much as may be, like, and sutable [suitable] to it self.

Fascination is a binding, which comes from the spirit of the Witch, through the eyes of him that is bewitched, entering to his heart. Now the instrument of Fascination is the spirit, viz. a certain pure, lucid, subtile vapour, generated of the purer blood, by the heat of the heart. This doth alwaies send forth, through the eyes, rayes like to it self; Those rayes being sent forth, do carry with them a spirituall vapour, and that vapour a blood, as it appears in bleer [bleary], and red eyes, whose raies [rays] being sent forth to the eyes of him that is opposite, and looks upon them, carries the vapour of the corrupt blood, together with it self, by the contagion of which, it doth infect the eyes of the beholder with the like disease. So the eye being opened, and intent upon any one with a strong imagination, doth dart its beams, which are the Vehiculum of the spirit into the eyes of him that is opposite to him, which tender spirit strikes the eyes of him that is bewitched, being stirred up from the heart of him that strikes, and possesseth the breast of him that is stricken, wounds his heart, and infects his spirit.

Magicians teach that Celestial gifts may through inferiors being conformable to superiors be drawn down by opportune influencies of the Heaven; and so also by these Celestial [gifts], the Celestial Angels, as they are servants of the Stars, may be procured, and conveyed to us. Iamblichus, Proclus, and Synesius, with the whole School of Platonists confirm, that not only Celestiall, and vitall, but also certain Intellectuall, Angelicall, and divine gifts may be received from above by some certain matters, having a naturall power of divinity (i.e.) which have a naturall correspondency with the superiors, being rightly received, and opportunely gathered together according to the rules of Naturall Philosophy, and Astronomy: And Mercurius Trismegistus writes, that an Image rightly made of certain proper things, appropriated to any one certain Angel, will presently be animated by that Angel.

The Philosophers, especially the Arabians, say, that mans mind, when it is most intent upon any work, through its passion, and effects, is joyned with the mind of the Stars, and Intelligencies, and being so joyned is the cause of some wonderfull vertue be infused into our works, and things; and this, as because there is in it an apprehension, and power of all things, so because all things have a naturall obedience to it, and of necessity an efficacy, and more to that which desires them with a strong desire.

It is well known to all, that there is a Certain vertue in the Loadstone, by which it attracts Iron, and that the Diamond doth by its presence take away that vertue of the Loadstone: so also Amber, and jeat [jet] rubbed, and warmed draw a straw to them, and the Stone Asbestus [asbestos] being once fired is never, or scarce extinguished: a Carbuncle shines in the dark, the Stone Aetites put above the young fruit of Women, or Plants, strengthens them, but being put under, causeth abortion; the Jasper stencheth [stauncheth] blood; the litle fish Echeneis stops the ships: Rhubarb expels choller [choler]; the liver of the Camelion [Chameleon] burnt, raiseth showers, and thunders. The Stone Heliotrope dazles [dazzles] the sight, and makes him that wears it to be invisible, the Stone Lyucurius takes away delusions from before the eyes, the perfume of the Stone Lypparis cals forth all the beasts, the Stone Synochitis brings up infernal Ghosts, the Stone Anachitis makes the images of the Gods appear. The Ennecis put under them that dream, causeth Oracles.

critical_analysis.relevance: Agrippa's 'Three Books of Occult Philosophy' is a foundational text in Western Esotericism, synthesizing Neoplatonism, Hermeticism, Kabbalah, and various magical traditions from antiquity through the Renaissance. Book I, in particular, lays out the theoretical and philosophical framework for natural magic, emphasizing the interconnectedness of the cosmos through a hierarchical system of correspondences. Its relevance lies in its systematic approach to magic as a learned discipline, rooted in a coherent cosmology, rather than mere superstition. It heavily influenced subsequent occultists like John Dee and Éliphas Lévi, and its discussions of elemental forces, planetary correspondences, sympathetic magic, and the power of the imagination remain central to many magical practices today. The text demonstrates how magic was perceived as a legitimate 'philosophy' and 'science' during the Renaissance, integrating diverse knowledge systems.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for 'Three Books of Occult Philosophy' would primarily be educated individuals with a strong background in philosophy (especially Platonic and Aristotelian thought), mathematics, astronomy, and theology. Agrippa explicitly states that a practitioner must be skilled in Natural Philosophy, Mathematicks, and Theologie. The text is dense, academic, and references numerous classical and obscure sources, suggesting it was intended for scholars, natural philosophers, alchemists, and serious practitioners of the occult who sought a comprehensive, theoretical understanding of the cosmos and its magical operations.
